Health Insurance in Washington: ACA Marketplace Guide
Learn about ACA health insurance options, subsidies, and enrollment in Washington. Educational guide from licensed agents.
Washington
WA
Washington Healthplanfinder
What is Washington Healthplanfinder?

Washington Healthplanfinder is the state-based health insurance exchange where Washington residents can compare and enroll in ACA-compliant health plans. It also serves as the portal for applying for Washington Apple Health (Medicaid) and determining eligibility for premium tax credits.
Does Washington offer any additional state-level health coverage programs?

Yes, Washington offers Cascade Care, a series of standardized health plans available through Washington Healthplanfinder that are designed to improve affordability and simplify plan comparison. The state has also introduced a public option component to further expand access to coverage.

## Health Insurance Options in Washington

Washington operates its own state-based exchange, Washington Healthplanfinder, for ACA Marketplace enrollment. The state has expanded Medicaid through Washington Apple Health, providing comprehensive coverage to low-income adults. For residents above the Medicaid income limit, Washington Healthplanfinder offers private health plans across the standard metal tiers. The state has also introduced Cascade Care plans, which are standardized options designed to improve transparency and affordability. Multiple insurers participate across Washington's rating regions, with the Puget Sound area generally offering the widest selection.

## How to Enroll in a Washington Healthplanfinder Plan

Enrollment takes place through the Washington Healthplanfinder website during the annual Open Enrollment period. The application collects household and income information to determine eligibility for Washington Apple Health, CHIP, or subsidized Marketplace coverage. Residents who experience qualifying life events can apply during a Special Enrollment Period. Washington Healthplanfinder provides tools for comparing plans by premium, deductible, network, and total estimated costs. Navigators, enrollment specialists called in-person assisters, and licensed insurance agents are available statewide to help with the application process at no cost.

## Subsidies and Financial Help in Washington

Federal premium tax credits are available to Washington residents who purchase coverage through Washington Healthplanfinder, with amounts determined by household income and the local benchmark Silver plan cost. Cost-sharing reductions on Silver plans lower out-of-pocket expenses for enrollees with qualifying incomes. Washington's Medicaid expansion through Apple Health provides comprehensive coverage for lower-income residents. The Cascade Care program and emerging public option offerings add further layers of affordability to Washington's insurance landscape, making the state one of the more progressive markets for accessible health coverage.

Health Insurance Income & Savings Calculator
Estimate how your household income affects ACA marketplace subsidies. Educational calculator for understanding premium tax credits.
How does income affect health insurance subsidies?
ACA premium tax credits are based on your household income relative to the Federal Poverty Level. Lower incomes generally result in larger subsidies that reduce monthly premium costs.
Is this calculator a guarantee of savings?
No. This is an educational estimate only. Actual subsidy amounts depend on your specific circumstances, available plans in your area, and current federal guidelines.

## What This Calculator Does

This calculator provides an educational estimate of how household income may affect ACA marketplace premium tax credits. By entering basic income and household information, the tool generates an approximate view of potential monthly savings on health insurance premiums.

The Affordable Care Act ties premium tax credit amounts to household income as a percentage of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Households earning between 100% and 400% of the FPL -- and in many cases above that threshold under extended subsidy rules -- may receive credits that lower monthly premium costs. This calculator models those relationships so users can better understand how income changes might influence financial assistance.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Start by entering total expected household income for the coverage year and the number of people in the household. The calculator then estimates where that income falls relative to the Federal Poverty Level and displays an approximate premium tax credit amount.

Results include an estimated monthly subsidy, an approximate percentage of income expected to go toward a benchmark plan premium, and a comparison showing costs with and without the estimated credit.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool is for informational and educational purposes only. It does not constitute financial, tax, or insurance advice. Actual premium tax credit amounts are determined by the Health Insurance Marketplace based on verified income, household size, age, location, and available plans. Consult a licensed insurance professional or visit HealthCare.gov for official eligibility determinations.

job-plan-affordability
Is My Job's Health Plan Affordable?
Check whether your employer health plan meets ACA affordability standards. Educational tool for understanding the employer coverage threshold.
What is the ACA affordability threshold?
For 2026, employer coverage is generally considered affordable if the employee-only premium does not exceed approximately 9.96% of household income.
What happens if my employer plan is not affordable?
If employer coverage is considered unaffordable under ACA guidelines, household members may be eligible to explore marketplace coverage with potential premium tax credits.

## What This Tool Does

This tool helps determine whether an employer-sponsored health plan meets the ACA affordability standard. The ACA defines employer coverage as affordable when the employee-only premium for the lowest-cost plan does not exceed a set percentage of household income -- approximately 9.96% for 2026.

Understanding this threshold matters because access to affordable employer coverage generally affects eligibility for marketplace premium tax credits. If employer-sponsored insurance is considered affordable under ACA rules, household members covered by that offer typically cannot receive marketplace subsidies. Conversely, if the employer plan exceeds the affordability threshold, marketplace options with financial assistance may become available.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Enter the monthly employee-only premium cost for the employer plan and the household's estimated annual income. The tool then calculates the premium as a percentage of income and compares it against the current affordability threshold.

Results display whether the employer plan falls above or below the ACA affordability standard, the exact percentage of income the premium represents, and general information about what that determination may mean for marketplace eligibility.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool provides general educational information only and does not constitute legal, tax, or benefits advice. Affordability determinations involve multiple factors, including specific employer offer details and household circumstances. For a binding eligibility determination, consult the Health Insurance Marketplace or a licensed benefits advisor.

plan-comparison
Compare Bronze, Silver & Gold Plans
Understand the differences between ACA metal tier plans. Educational comparison of Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum health insurance levels.
What is the difference between Bronze, Silver, and Gold plans?

The metal tiers differ in how costs are shared. Bronze plans have lower premiums but higher out-of-pocket costs. Gold plans have higher premiums but lower costs when you use care. Silver plans fall in between.
Which plan level is best?
There is no single best plan level. The right choice depends on your healthcare needs, budget, and whether you qualify for cost-sharing reductions, which only apply to Silver plans.

## What This Tool Does

This tool provides an educational comparison of ACA metal tier plan levels. The Affordable Care Act organizes marketplace health insurance into four metal tiers -- Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum -- each representing a different balance between monthly premiums and out-of-pocket costs when receiving care.

Bronze plans cover approximately 60% of average healthcare costs, leaving 40% to the enrollee. Silver plans cover about 70%, Gold about 80%, and Platinum about 90%. A key distinction is that cost-sharing reductions (CSRs) are available only with Silver plans for eligible lower-income households, which can significantly reduce deductibles and copays beyond what the standard Silver tier offers.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Review the side-by-side breakdown of each metal tier to compare typical premium ranges, deductible levels, copay structures, and out-of-pocket maximums. The tool highlights the trade-offs between paying more each month in premiums versus paying more at the point of care.

Results also explain how cost-sharing reductions interact specifically with Silver plans and why that feature can make Silver the most cost-effective option for many households.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool is for informational and educational purposes only. Actual plan costs, benefits, and availability vary by location, insurer, and enrollment period. The figures presented are general illustrations of how metal tiers work, not quotes for specific plans. Contact the Health Insurance Marketplace or a licensed insurance agent for plan-specific details.

what-income-counts
What Income Counts for Health Insurance?
Understand how Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) is calculated for ACA health insurance purposes. Educational guide to income counting.
What is MAGI for health insurance?
Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) is the income figure used to determine eligibility for ACA premium tax credits. It starts with your Adjusted Gross Income and adds back certain deductions.
Does this tool replace tax advice?
No. This tool provides general educational information about how income is typically counted for ACA purposes. Consult a tax professional for advice about your specific situation.

## What This Tool Does

This tool explains which types of income are counted when determining eligibility for ACA health insurance subsidies. The ACA uses Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) as its primary income measure, and understanding what MAGI includes is an important step in estimating potential financial assistance.

MAGI starts with Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) from a federal tax return and adds back three specific items: non-taxable Social Security benefits, tax-exempt interest income, and foreign earned income that was excluded from AGI. Common income sources included in AGI -- and therefore in MAGI -- are wages, salary, self-employment income, retirement distributions, investment income, and alimony received under pre-2019 agreements.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Select or review each income category to see whether it typically counts toward MAGI. The tool walks through common income types, identifies which ones are included, and provides brief explanations for each category.

Results offer a clearer picture of which income sources generally factor into ACA subsidy calculations and which are typically excluded, such as gifts, veterans' disability payments, and child support received.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool is for educational purposes only and does not provide tax or financial advice. Income counting rules can vary based on individual circumstances and changes in federal regulation. For guidance specific to a particular tax situation, consult a qualified tax professional or visit IRS.gov.

Cost-Sharing Reduction (CSR) Eligibility Estimator
Estimate whether your income may qualify for ACA cost-sharing reductions that lower deductibles, copays, and out-of-pocket maximums on Silver marketplace plans.
What are cost-sharing reductions and how do they work?

Cost-sharing reductions (CSRs) are ACA benefits that lower out-of-pocket costs on Silver marketplace plans. When eligible, the insurance company reduces deductibles, copays, and maximum out-of-pocket limits. CSRs are only available on Silver-tier plans and are based on household income relative to the Federal Poverty Level.
Do I need to apply separately for cost-sharing reductions?

No. When enrolling in a marketplace plan, eligibility for cost-sharing reductions is determined automatically based on the income information provided in the application. If eligible, CSR benefits are applied only when a Silver plan is selected.
Can I get cost-sharing reductions on Bronze or Gold plans?
No. Cost-sharing reductions are exclusively available on Silver-tier marketplace plans. Choosing a Bronze, Gold, or Platinum plan means forgoing CSR benefits even if income would otherwise qualify.

## What This Tool Does

This estimator helps individuals and families understand whether their household income may qualify for ACA cost-sharing reductions. CSRs are a significant but often overlooked benefit that can dramatically reduce healthcare costs beyond what premium tax credits provide. The tool calculates income as a percentage of the Federal Poverty Level and shows what level of cost-sharing reduction may apply.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Enter household size and annual income to see an estimated CSR tier. The tool displays approximate deductible amounts, out-of-pocket maximums, and typical copay levels for each eligibility tier. Results compare the enhanced Silver plan benefits against a standard Silver plan to illustrate the potential savings.

### Educational Disclaimer

This is an educational estimate and not a guarantee of eligibility. Actual cost-sharing reduction levels are determined by the Health Insurance Marketplace based on verified income and household information. Plan-specific costs vary by insurer and region.

family-coverage-estimator
Family Health Insurance Cost Estimator
Estimate monthly health insurance costs for your family based on household size, income, and plan tier. Understand how ACA subsidies may reduce your premiums.
How are family health insurance premiums calculated on the marketplace?

Marketplace premiums are based on the ages of household members, location, tobacco use, and the plan selected. Premium tax credits reduce the cost based on household income relative to the Federal Poverty Level. The subsidy is calculated using the second-lowest-cost Silver plan as a benchmark.
Are children covered differently than adults on marketplace plans?

Children under 21 generally have lower base premiums than adults. Up to three children of the same age are rated, meaning families with more than three children of similar ages do not pay additional premiums for the fourth child and beyond.
Can a family save money by splitting into separate marketplace applications?

In some cases, married couples may find that filing separately or exploring different coverage combinations could affect subsidy eligibility. However, this depends on specific tax filing circumstances and income levels. Consulting with a licensed agent or navigator is recommended.

## What This Tool Does

This estimator helps families understand the approximate monthly cost of ACA marketplace health insurance based on their household composition and income. It calculates the expected premium contribution as a percentage of income and estimates the potential premium tax credit that may reduce monthly costs across different plan tiers.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Select the number of adults and children in the household, enter total annual household income, and choose a plan tier. The tool displays estimated monthly premiums before and after potential subsidies, showing the approximate out-of-pocket cost for coverage. Results include comparisons across Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum tiers.

### Educational Disclaimer

This is an educational estimate based on national averages and general ACA subsidy formulas. Actual premiums vary significantly by geographic rating area, age of household members, tobacco use, and specific plan selection. Use Healthcare.gov or a state exchange for accurate premium quotes.
